user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleWrite:
```c
int32 OS_ConsoleWrite(osal_id_t console_id, const char *Str)
{
    int32                         return_code;
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *console;
    size_t                        PendingWritePos;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE, console_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        console = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, token);

        /*
         * The entire string should be put to the ring buffer,
         * or none of it.  Therefore the WritePos in the table
         * is not updated until complete success.
         */
        PendingWritePos = console->WritePos;

        if (console->device_name[0] != 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_Console_CopyOut(console, console->device_name, &PendingWritePos);
        }
        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return_code = OS_Console_CopyOut(console, Str, &PendingWritePos);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* the entire message was successfully written */
            console->WritePos = PendingWritePos;
        }
        else
        {
            /* the message did not fit */
            ++console->OverflowEvents;
        }

        /*
         * Notify the underlying console implementation of new data.
         * This will forward the data to the actual console device.
         *
         * This is done while still locked, so it can support
         * either a synchronous or asynchronous implementation.
         */
        if (console->IsAsync)
        {
            /* post the sem for the utility task to run */
            OS_ConsoleWakeup_Impl(&token);
        }
        else
        {
            /* output directly */
            OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&token);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter of OS_ConsoleWrite is modified in this function. The parameters are:
- console_id (passed by value) — used as an argument but never assigned to or incremented.
- Str (const char *) — passed to OS_Console_CopyOut but not assigned or otherwise altered in this function. The pointer variable Str itself is not modified; only the object pointed-to could be modified by callees (and it is declared const here, preventing modification).
Other potentially-looking lines were inspected and do not violate Rule 17.8:
- Calls to OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_Console_CopyOut, OS_ConsoleWakeup_Impl, OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl, and OS_ObjectIdRelease pass parameters but do not modify this function's parameters.
- Modifications such as PendingWritePos = console->WritePos, console->WritePos = PendingWritePos, and ++console->OverflowEvents affect local variables or fields of objects reached via local pointers (console) and not the function parameters. Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by the rule; however, no such modification to *Str occurs here.
Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
